awd_titl_txt: S&AS: INT: Autonomous Experimentation Platform for Accelerating Manufacturing of Advanced Materials
awd_abstract_narration:
Discovering and manufacturing new materials is a laborious and time-consuming process.  Historically this process takes significant effort from material scientists and manufacturing engineers as they explore many different ingredient compositions and process conditions to find the right combination leading to a material with the desired properties.  This project is developing an autonomous experimentation platform to replace a significant amount of this human effort in experimentation and thus accelerate the discovery and manufacturing of advanced materials.  Such an autonomous experimental testbed could have significant impacts on engineering practice and revolutionize the material discovery and advanced manufacturing landscape.  This would in turn accelerate discovery in materials for a great number of industries and applications. Students to be involved in the project will receive training with a blend of data science and material/manufacturing science.  

This project introduces artificial intelligence and autonomy modules into an autonomous experimentation platform to mimic a human scientist's ability to handle surprising observations, synthesize diverse bodies of knowledge, and explore a complex and large design space. The key research components in this platform are organized around three capabilities themes: (1) exploitation to efficiently determine the most promising regions of a design space, (2) exploration to recognize and reason about surprises arising from unusual designs, and (3) expansion of newly-discovered design space based on mining new knowledge from literature and databases, preferentially gaining knowledge in regions likely to contain superior material design solutions.  The proposed system is cognizant, adaptive, knowledge-rich and taskable, interacting with human scientists by way of simple commands and executing an autonomous discovery process with a minimal and appropriate degree of human intervention.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering

por.por_cntn:
A multi-disciplinary team successfully developed an autonomous system aimed at revolutionizing the discovery and manufacturing of materials, fundamentally transforming the process into a more efficient and less resource-intensive endeavor. Central to this project was the exploration and implementation of a surprise-reacting decision metric, which proved superior to traditional Bayesian optimization methods by effectively navigating the complex landscape of material properties and thus accelerating the discovery process. In parallel, the team tackled the automation of the polishing process in additive manufacturing, a critical bottleneck due to its heavy reliance on manual labor, by linking process parameters and sensor data to surface quality, enabling automated, real-time decision-making. Additionally, the project made significant progress toward the functional calibration of digital twins, developing a theoretical framework and algorithmic solutions to accurately reflect the variability of physical systems, enhancing simulation fidelity. A concerted effort to integrate diverse computational and experimental data sources shed new light on the importance of microstructural states in material discovery, offering nuanced insights into material behavior. Furthermore, the application of Graph Neural Networks opened new avenues for analyzing complex data structures, significantly contributing to the decision-making processes in material science. Collectively, these research thrusts demonstrate a significant advancement in the acceleration of materials discovery and process optimization through AI-enabled techniques.


Last Modified: 04/05/2024
Modified by: Raymundo Arroyave
